presentations.title: Network Infrastructure Research
presentations.description: A comprehensive technical research covering broadband access technologies, network protocols, and content delivery systems.

sections.title: Network Infrastructure Research
sections.subtitle: Technical Documentation
sections.content: An in-depth exploration of modern broadband technologies, network protocols, and content delivery systems used in telecommunications infrastructure.

sections.title: Triple-play Service
sections.content: Triple-play service refers to a business that provides Internet, TV (general broadcast and OTT), and telephone in one bundle. This bundled approach allows service providers to offer comprehensive communication solutions to consumers.

sections.title: Home Gateway
sections.content: Home gateway is a device that works as both router and modem. Its responsibility is to connect to ISP's network and distribute the internet to local devices.

sections.title: VLAN (Virtual LAN)
sections.content: VLAN logically segments a single physical network into multiple separate broadcast domains. This allows devices to communicate as if they were on their own private LAN. A subnet mask is a 32-bit number used in IPv4 networking that helps divide an IP address into the network portion and the host portion.

items.title: Access Port
items.description: A switchport which belongs to a single VLAN, and usually connects to end hosts like PCs (untagged port).

items.title: Trunk Port
items.description: Switchports which carry multiple VLANs (tagged port). Uses 802.1Q tagging.

items.title: Native VLAN
items.description: VLAN 1 by default on all trunk ports. The switch does not add 802.1Q tag to frames in the native VLAN.

items.title: VLAN Range
items.description: VLANs 1, 1002-1005 cannot be deleted. Normal range: 1-1005, Extended range: 1006-4094.

sections.title: Ethernet Frame Structure
sections.content: Standard Ethernet frame structure showing the preamble, destination, source, type/length, data, and FCS fields.

sections.title: 802.1Q VLAN Tag
sections.content: The 802.1Q tag is 4 bytes (32 bits) inserted between source and type/length. TPID is always 0x8100, and TCI contains PCP (priority), DEI (drop eligible), and VID (VLAN ID - 12 bits for 4096 VLANs).

sections.title: Cisco VLAN Configuration Commands
sections.content:
show vlan brief
interface range g1/0 - 3
switchport mode access
switchport access vlan 10
vlan 10
name THE_NAME_TO_VLAN

# Trunk Configuration
interface g0/0
switchport mode trunk
switchport trunk encapsulation dot1q
show interfaces trunk

sections.title: GPON (Gigabit Passive Optical Network)
sections.content: GPON is a technology for connecting to the Internet by fiber optic cable. It provides high-speed and stable communication without unnecessary speed losses or failures, and without active equipment on the line. Fiber optic internet is effective because of its energy independence and it does not lose signal over long distances.

items.title: OLT (Optical Line Terminal)
items.description: Located at the service provider's data center. Sends downstream signals at 1550nm (video) and 1490nm (voice/data), receives upstream at 1310nm.

items.title: Optical Fiber Splitter
items.description: Passive component that splits a single fiber into multiple strands (ratios: 1:64, 1:32, 1:16, 1:8, 1:4) for individual connections.

items.title: ONU/ONT (Optical Network Terminal)
items.description: Installed at home or office. Converts optical signals to electrical signals for routers, TVs, and computers.

sections.title: GPON Network Architecture
sections.content: GPON network topology showing the flow from OLT through splitters to multiple ONT endpoints.

items.title: Step 1: Transmission
items.description: Provider equipment transmits data using WDM (Wavelength Division Multiplexing) technology, allowing multiple signals over a single fiber.

items.title: Step 2: Splitting
items.description: The signal passes through the optical network and reaches the passive splitter, which divides it into separate signals.

items.title: Step 3: Reception
items.description: The signal reaches your ONU at home, connects to your router, and provides Internet access. Works bidirectionally up to 20km.

sections.title: MDU (Multi-Dwelling Unit) Switch
sections.content: MDU switch is a networking device designed for large residential or commercial buildings (like apartment blocks or dorms) to efficiently distribute internet services. It acts as a central point connecting many users using FTTB (Fiber to the Building), supporting VLANs, PPSK for secure Wi-Fi, and centralized management.

sections.title: BRAS (Broadband Remote Access Server)
sections.content: BRAS is the bridge between the access network and the backbone network. It is a gateway that controls user data in and out of the backbone, performing authentication and billing by cooperating with authentication and billing systems. It's like a toll booth of the highway, managing and billing users.

sections.title: BRAS Architecture
sections.content: BRAS positioned between the access network and backbone network, connecting to core routers.

sections.title: DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol)
sections.content: DHCP is a network management protocol used on IP networks for automatically assigning IP addresses and other communication parameters to devices. It eliminates the need for individually configuring network devices manually using a client-server architecture.

items.title: Dynamic Allocation
items.description: Administrator reserves a range of IP addresses. DHCP uses lease concept with controllable time period for address reclamation.

items.title: Automatic Allocation
items.description: DHCP server permanently assigns IP addresses while keeping a table of past assignments for preferential assignment.

items.title: Manual Allocation (Static)
items.description: Administrator maps unique identifier (client ID or MAC address) to specific IP address. Also called reservation or MAC/IP binding.

sections.title: Internet Exchange Point (IXP)
sections.content: An IXP is a physical location where Internet infrastructure companies such as ISPs and CDNs connect with each other. These exist on the 'edge' of different networks, allowing providers to share transit outside their own network, reducing latency and potentially reducing costs.

sections.title: The Trombone Effect
sections.content: Without IXPs, local traffic can travel vast distances to be exchanged and return, known as tromboning. IXPs eliminate this inefficiency.

items.title: Transit
items.description: Paid agreement between customer and upstream provider for full connectivity to the rest of the Internet using BGP.

items.title: Peering
items.description: Networks sharing IP addresses without intermediary. At IXPs, transferring data is often free (settlement-free peering).

items.title: PNI (Private Network Interconnect)
items.description: Dark fiber connection directly between two networks within a datacenter when traffic volume justifies dedicated connection.

items.title: Depeering
items.description: Process of ending a peering arrangement, often due to imbalanced traffic ratios or monetization decisions.

items.title: MISPA-IXP
items.description: MISPA internet exchange point

items.title: MIX MNDC
items.description: Mongolian Internet Exchange & Mongolian National Data Center

sections.title: CDN (Content Delivery Network)
sections.content: A CDN distributes content across geographically distributed servers to deliver data quickly to users. It consists of Origin servers (storing and updating data), Edge servers (delivering from nearest location), and DNS servers (translating domains and routing requests).

items.title: Public CDN
items.description: Accessible to everybody online with a vast global network of servers.

items.title: Private CDN
items.description: Dedicated CDN infrastructure for a single organization.

items.title: P2P CDN
items.description: Uses peer-to-peer networking to distribute content directly between users.

items.title: Hybrid CDN
items.description: Combines public and private CDN elements for optimized delivery.

items.title: Push CDN
items.description: Content uploaded to CDN in advance, good for large static files.

items.title: Pull CDN
items.description: Content fetched on demand, efficient for frequently updated content.

items.title: Step 1: Request
items.description: User sends a request for content (e.g., an image) from a website.

items.title: Step 2: Routing
items.description: CDN identifies user's location and routes request to nearest edge server.

items.title: Step 3: Cache Check
items.description: If content is cached at edge server, it's delivered directly to user.

items.title: Step 4: Origin Fetch
items.description: If not cached, edge server retrieves from origin, caches locally, then delivers.

items.title: Step 5: Caching
items.description: Cached content stored at edge server for future requests, optimizing performance.

presentations.title: ISP Network Architecture
presentations.description: A comprehensive technical deep-dive into Triple Play services, Access Networks, Fixed Core, and GPON technology.

sections.title: ISP Network Architecture
sections.subtitle: Technical Deep Dive
sections.content: Understanding the layered architecture of modern ISP networks: from fiber access to core routing, service delivery, and content optimization.

sections.title: Triple Play Service
sections.content: Triple Play represents the convergence of Internet, IPTV, and VoIP over a single broadband infrastructure. In modern GPON-based networks, this convergence is achieved by logical separation rather than physical segregation.

items.title: Internet Traffic (VLAN 100)
items.description: Best-effort unicast traffic for web browsing, downloads, and general connectivity.

items.title: IPTV Traffic (VLAN 200)
items.description: Multicast for live TV channels, unicast for on-demand video (VOD) content.

items.title: VoIP Traffic (VLAN 300)
items.description: Low-latency, real-time unicast streams requiring priority QoS treatment.

sections.title: Traffic Routing in Triple Play
sections.content: Internet and VoIP traffic routes through BRAS for subscriber authentication and policy enforcement, while IPTV traffic bypasses BRAS and reaches the SPINE switch directly. QoS is enforced end-to-end, ensuring VoIP and IPTV maintain priority during high Internet usage.

items.title: ONT
items.description: Handles VLAN tagging at customer premises, separating Triple Play services at ingress.

items.title: OLT
items.description: Performs traffic shaping, multicast replication for IPTV, and upstream scheduling.

items.title: BRAS
items.description: Manages subscriber authentication, IP policy enforcement, and AAA accounting.

sections.title: Access Network
sections.content: The access network is the physical and logical path connecting subscriber devices to the first provider-managed service node. It handles traffic encapsulation, VLAN tagging, and QoS marking but does not perform IP routing or subscriber authentication‚Äîthose are tasks for BRAS and HCORE.

items.title: CPE/Home Gateway
items.description: Customer premises equipment providing WiFi, routing, and service demarcation.

items.title: ONT/MDU
items.description: Optical Network Terminal converting fiber signals to Ethernet for the subscriber.

items.title: Optical Splitter
items.description: Passive device splitting one fiber into multiple subscriber connections (1:32 or 1:64).

items.title: OLT
items.description: Optical Line Terminal at the central office managing all ONTs in the PON tree.

items.title: Metro Cluster
items.description: Active-Standby aggregation switches providing redundancy and uplink diversity.

sections.title: High Availability in Access
sections.content: The access network ensures reliability using Active-Standby Metro clusters and redundant OLT uplinks. IPTV multicast replication and VoIP QoS tagging are handled at this layer. Most subscriber-level outages occur here: ONT failures, split fiber cuts, or local power issues. Metro switch and OLT uplink failures are mitigated by HA mechanisms.

sections.title: Fixed Core Network
sections.content: The Fixed Core network is the intelligence and aggregation layer for all subscriber traffic. It consists of BRAS, HCORE, SIG, and IGW/MIX. This layer provides subscriber authentication, IP assignment, policy enforcement, routing, NAT, and external peering.

items.title: BRAS
items.description: Subscriber edge device handling authentication, IP assignment (private/public), policy, and AAA.

items.title: HCORE
items.description: Aggregates BRAS traffic, implements routing/traffic engineering, directs flows to SIG or CDN.

items.title: SIG
items.description: Provides NAT (CGNAT for private IPs), security filtering, and external peering to Internet/MIX.

items.title: IGW/MIX
items.description: Internet Gateway and Mongolian Internet Exchange for public peering and transit.

items.title: Dual IP Support
items.description: Supports both private IP subscribers (CGNAT at SIG) and public IP subscribers with direct routing.

items.title: Session Persistence
items.description: Maintains seamless connectivity and session persistence during BRAS failover events.

items.title: CDN Integration
items.description: Interfaces with HCDN for efficient content distribution, caching, and reduced transit costs.

sections.title: GPON Technology
sections.content: GPON (Gigabit Passive Optical Network) is the access technology backbone for modern fiber broadband. It multiplexes multiple subscribers over a single fiber using Time-Division Multiple Access (TDMA) for upstream and broadcast for downstream.

items.title: ONT Identification
items.description: Each ONT is identified by serial and port ID, authenticated via OLT using PLOAM messages.

items.title: Downstream Encryption
items.description: Traffic is encrypted per ONT using AES-128, ensuring subscriber privacy on shared fiber.

items.title: Bandwidth Allocation
items.description: Deterministic bandwidth per subscriber through T-CONT and Dynamic Bandwidth Allocation (DBA).

items.title: Multicast Efficiency
items.description: IPTV multicast streams are replicated efficiently at the OLT, reducing upstream bandwidth.

sections.title: GPON Scalability
sections.content: GPON enables the access network to scale to thousands of subscribers while preserving QoS and HA. Service separation (Internet, IPTV, VoIP) occurs at the physical layer with VLAN-based isolation. Unicast VOD flows are forwarded to SPINE switches while multicast is replicated at OLT level.

sections.title: Unified Architecture View
sections.content: Together, Triple Play, Access Network, Fixed Core, and GPON form a layered architecture that delivers reliable, scalable, and differentiated services to subscribers.

items.title: Layer 1: GPON
items.description: Fiber-based physical foundation connecting subscriber premises to metro aggregation.

items.title: Layer 2: Access Network
items.description: ONTs, splitters, OLTs, and metro clusters ensuring HA and proper service separation.

items.title: Layer 3: Fixed Core
items.description: Subscriber logic, routing, policy enforcement, NAT, and content optimization.

items.title: Layer 4: Triple Play Services
items.description: Internet, IPTV, and VoIP delivered over these layers with VLANs and QoS ensuring coexistence.

sections.title: Unified Analysis Capability
sections.content: Understanding these four components together allows you to analyze packet flows, failure points, IP mapping, multicast delivery, and redundancy mechanisms. This knowledge is essential for troubleshooting, capacity planning, and network optimization in ISP environments.
